title: Georgia House - Day 28 (2026-03-06)
summary:
Overview:
The Georgia House session on 2026-03-06 featured debate and passage of several bills, including legislation related to professional licensing reforms and tracking foreign funding at state universities.

Key Actions:
**HB 579**: Provides reforms to the state's professional licensing system, including giving the licensing division more authority and allowing boards to focus on disciplining bad actors.
**HB 549**: Extends the window for law enforcement agencies to seek reimbursement for training expenses when an officer leaves for another agency, from 15 months to 36 months.
**HB 150**: Requires the University System of Georgia to report quarterly on any funding received from "foreign countries of concern" beyond standard tuition payments.

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
No new bills were introduced during this session.

Notable Moments:
- Rep. Reaves presented HB 579, highlighting how the bill modernizes professional licensing and improves services for constituents and small businesses.
- Rep. Seabolt presented HB 549, explaining how it helps law enforcement agencies recoup training costs when officers leave for other agencies.
- Rep. Fleming presented HB 150, which aims to increase transparency around foreign funding at state universities. There was some debate around the scope of the reporting requirements.

Votes:
- HB 579 passed 158-2.
- HB 549 passed 164-0. 
- HB 150 passed, but the vote count was not explicitly stated.

Attendance:
A quorum was present, as all members were called to the floor at the start of the session.

Adjournment:
The House adjourned, but the transcript does not specify the exact time or the date of the next scheduled session.
